turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Holy God! The mummy walks!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: How dare you? My father is the British Museum's most respected archeologist!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Do they have him on display at the weekends?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: God, you're so obnoxious! Our work happens to be of great anthropological value!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Value? ... Value?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm sorry ...

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Where do I charter a boat?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: There's nothing fast enough to catch that. Forget it. It's over.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I not doing this for me, Jack! It's for my father. This is possibly the greatest anthropological discovery of the last two hundred years! It belongs to him! I'm going to that island ... nothing's going to stop me!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Can you fly?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Are you kidding?! That heap of junk will never leave the ground!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah! Life's looking pretty damn good at the moment.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I don't know what happened to you, Jack ... but I can't believe you were always this much of a bastard.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: When this boat finally reaches Jakata, I'll be first off. You'll never see me again ... and believe me - that day cannot come soon enough. I've got no problem with you ignoring me for the rest of the voyage.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I want to thank you.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It's ok.I know what you were feeling.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: I can't imagine you crying.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Relax ... it was fifteen years ago. I don't do it now.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: There's a light up ahead.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Sun's coming up ...  We've been in the fog for six hours.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It's the same image - Kong!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Leave it, Ann.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Jack!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We're leaving.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: But . . . we can' t Jack, I need time to collect artifacts ... make sketches ... gather evidential information.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Ann ... you're father is dead. You have nothing to prove anymore.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Oh Jesus ... you took it.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Jack! This is the archeological find of the century!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: This shit is bad luck! Don't you understand? You treat it like a game - two men have already died!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Give it back!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm not sailing with this thing on board!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: No! Don't!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Barricade the gates! Quick!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Jack!...  Jack!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Jesus Christ ! How could you do this to him? How could you do this?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Come on, come on! We gotta keep moving!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: He's gonna die! They'll kill him!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Take to look out there ..- Have you seen what he's done? You're talking about a crazy animal!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: You're the animals - all of you!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Ann ... Ann!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: It' s alright Jack ... it' s alright.

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: Look, I've sailed these waters for twenty-seven years ... there's no island like that around here.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: What a climax to the film - The first white men to set foot on ...  "Skull Island"  Twentieth Century man comes face to face with a ... a ... naked stone age tribe!

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: I tell you it doesn't exist!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: We need those co-ordinates -someone's gotta get back there and jot the rest of it down

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: There's no island there. We're wasting our time!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: I'm chartering this vessel,Engelhorn - how many days?

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: Two... maybe three.

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: I guess that answers your questions. There's no island on these co- ordinates - not even a lousy fog-bank.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Well, that was a monumental waste of time! I pay good money, only to be taken on some wild goose chase!  I made the mistake of trusting my idiot translator!

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: They're stoking the boilers. As soon as we've got some steam, we're outta here.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: We should never have come! I pay you good money, only to have my life endangered. You'll be hearing from my lawyer!

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: Just take it easy .-- Where are the others?

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: They' re dead.

turns.speaker: ENGLEHORN
turns.text: Oh my God ... Ann?

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Pleased to meet you ... Hi, bow's it going? Pleased to meet you! Hi, Carl Denham ... How's it going?

turns.speaker: MR GINTING
turns.text: We offer ourselves at your service, Mr Denham!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: And I appreciate that so much, I really do - a sentiment that will be shared by audiences across America when they view my latest documentary sensation "Indonesia ...Hell Hole of the World". Ernie Hemmingway's agreed to write the narration. We're going out through Universal ... Laemmale's promised me fifteen hundred screens.

turns.speaker: MR GINTING
turns.text: You are most kind. We will be proud to assist you!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Exotic lands, primitive people, dangerous animals ... That's what the public expect from a Carl Denham picture! Lead us into the mountains, Sir!

turns.speaker: MR GINTING
turns.text: The mountains?

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Tell me Mr Ginting - are there any parts of your country where people still wear ... native costume?

turns.speaker: MR GINTING
turns.text: Native costume?

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Y'know ... traditional ceremonies where the woman ... divest themselves of their undergarments.

turns.speaker: MR GINTING
turns.text: We are a very modest and deeply religious people, Mr Denham.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: MR GINTING
turns.text: Man Eater!!!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: A man eater! Fantastic!  Making history, Herb

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Did you see her?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah, I saw her ... she was carried into the jungle by ... an animal.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: What was it, Jack?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: An ape ... some kind of ape.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Listen buddy! Cut the crap! We're looking for Ann, not making a Goddamn movie!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Jack ... You get to save the girl and I get my third act! It's gonna be good for you and good for me!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You better not slow us down, Denham!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Holy shit! Look at the size of that!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: That's your monkey, Denham.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Kong ...

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Hey! I thought these things were supposed to be extinct!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: ) They are now.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: They were just tasting the berries.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Yeah? ... Well, I gave 'em a taste of American lead ... and I don't see 'em coming back for seconds!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Set up the camera boys! Get a shot of me comin' ashore!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Forget it, Denham ... for Godssake

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: I'm calling a wrap. We're heading back to the ship.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: The girl's dead, Driscoll. There's no point continuing on.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Denham! Go back to the wall ... Tell'em to give me twelve hours to get back with Ann!

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: I can't get back to the wall! I'll get eaten!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Not me. Thought I'd head out west ... get into some Redwood country.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: How about Ann? Is she going with you?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Haven't seen her - not since we got back.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: She's got a bit of an attitude, that girl. She's turned down a bunch of money. Too bad ... it would've been a great angle - "Beauty and the Beast".  I must be getting old - I thought you two had something going there.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Are you nervous Jack?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Nab- Let's get it over with.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: Did you fear for your life?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DENHAM
turns.text: It must have been terrifying?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: Are you gonna start it up?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Coz of something I lost.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Compassion.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: What's compassion, mister.

turns.speaker: ARLYN
turns.text: Bree -- honey - please, we're waiting for someone.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Arlyn, he just wanted to ask some questions -- something you could help us about.

turns.speaker: ARLYN
turns.text: Can't you see I'm strung out?  Please, we're waiting for it -- he's got to have it!

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Honey, a couple of years ago, with Jane and Frankie? -- Jane sent me a Dumper --

turns.speaker: ARLYN
turns.text: Please, if he sees you, he won't come!

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Arlyn, just tell me, did Jane have a dumper, one of her regular Johns?

turns.speaker: ARLYN
turns.text: What about him? Yes.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Did he come around often?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Trina this is Klute. I told you about him.

turns.speaker: TRINA
turns.text: Oh yes Mr. Klute -- won't you both join me?  And how do you like our fair city? There's so much here don't you think? The museums and the books and the foreign films -- Bree, have you seen the Godard film?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Uh uh.

turns.speaker: TRINA
turns.text: Oh you've got to. He does such fun things with imagery. And I've been reading The Fall --  -- The Fall by Ahlbair Camoo -- it's the same thing, you know the imagery --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Trina honey, he just wants to find Arlyn Page.

turns.speaker: TRINA
turns.text: Why? She's a junkie.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: She was with you after she left Frank.

turns.speaker: TRINA
turns.text: Well she's not now.  I did everything for Arlyn. I loved Arlyn I took her right into my apartment, my own sweet apartment on First. But she wouldn't stay off it -- the junk -- and I wept and I pleaded and I held her in my arms - and she started taking things, my things, and selling them for horse. My clothes. We could've had everything together, everything -- and then the bitch sold my mink!

turns.speaker: MR. FABER
turns.text: Enjoy.  Well --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: It's good to see you. Well -- could we do it first and then just talk?

turns.speaker: MR. FABER
turns.text: Sure dear, yes.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well -- well I'm just back. And -- I must tell you -- something quite wonderful.

turns.speaker: MR. FABER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: And Cannes was quite fun, quite; and we played baccarat and chemindefer and there was a nice little Italian marquis quite enthusiastic for me -- but a young man can be so silly --

turns.speaker: MR. FABER
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: And then one night -- at the gaming tables -- well I just saw him. A stranger -- looking at me -- and I knew suddenly that all my life I'd been --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: -- May I? It's so --

turns.speaker: MR. FABER
turns.text: Please --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Not young; he wasn't young -- gray at the temples, he -- well actually he looked like you.

turns.speaker: MR. FABER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: And nobody could tell me who he was -- an exiled prince or a mercenary or a bullfighter or -- but I felt it stirring inside me, this -- this wild, pagan feeling --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I know: it's ridiculous. But it's tearing me up and I don't know why. And look, all right, I came here didn't I? And if I have to, I'll keep coming here, the works, and talk about my mummy and my daddy and I'll even pay for it, but will you kindly for God's sakes say something?

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: I'd just be guessing.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Guess!

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: Maybe this wasn't just a trick. Maybe you're in danger of real love, real involve --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I do not love him.

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: You've spent your life avoiding this. You'll try hard to deny it; you're quite likely to destroy it.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: All right. Loneliness.  Well -- separated. From other people. Forgotten.  Well, as if I can be here, I can go through the motions, right? But the truth is, I don't belong.

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: Don't belong?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Do you always have to repeat?

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well it's more than loneliness. Hate. People hating me -- and watching me and following and waiting to hurt me -- you know? I'm all screwed up.

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: You think people hate you.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: The truth is I hate them: they must hate me. All right, the money.  All right, not the money. A kind of put-on. It gets things back together.  Well let's say I'd go to one of these cattle-calls, a tryout. I mean before -- before I got this job -- and they'd always say thank you very much and i'd feel, you know, brought down. They didn't want me.

turns.speaker: SPANGLER
turns.text: Didn't want you.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I said that.  Well, so you have a choice. You can either feel lonely -- you know, the hate -- or --  So you take a call and go to a hotel room and there's some John you've never seen before, but he wants you. He must, he's paying for it.  And usually they're nervous and that's all right, too, because you're not; you know this thing. And then for a while, boy, they really pay attention, you're all there is.  And it's not real and you don't have to even like them -- you can even hate them, it's all right, it safe -- you know?

turns.speaker: LELA
turns.text: -- I have to close up now. Leave your name and number with his message service, Mrs. Daniel, and why don't you just go home and wait until he --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LELA
turns.text: Well I have to close up now.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Look -- could I use your phone?

turns.speaker: LELA
turns.text: Yes indeed.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Look. I almost killed my -- I almost killed someone.

turns.speaker: LELA
turns.text: Well I'm certain Doctor Spangler will want to talk with you; excuse me.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Miss Daniel, be sensible, you find another place till we get things cleaned up.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh well that shouldn't take you more than another, oh, two and a half or three years, should it?

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: A few more days. We know who did this.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: So do I.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: No, not Grunemann. He's dead. The man that killed him -- also prob'ly Jane McKenna, also Arlyn Page.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Arlyn and Jane commited suicide. He said they commited suicide.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Now there's a picture I'd like you to --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You said someone killed them, you said you know who, you said that.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Well we're pretty --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Why isn't he locked up?

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: We don't want to just lock him up; we want a conviction, we wanted him to do something more.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Is that why Klute didn't tell me?

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: I guess he figured it was better.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What was better? I made better bait?

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: No, that's not --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Is that what he set me up for? Everything he's told me from the beginning? -- don't worry, don't --

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: From the beginning I don't know why the hell he's messin with you. If he was me he'd know better. If he was even a city boy he'd know better. You're a whore Miss Daniel, that's the truth of it, right? Now somethin I'd like you to look at.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I don't have to look at anything. I don't have --

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Here please.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh no.

turns.speaker: TRASK
turns.text: Like for you to look for the man.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Grunemann? I've looked at him a --

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Can't we talk together reasonably, just -- ordinarily?  I know you're expecting some kind of -- extravagant behavior, but believe me -- do you believe me? --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Yes -- all right --

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: -- We can talk --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: -- Yes.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: All right, then, an ordinary matter. I'm a quite well off man, I have a -- position to respect. I would feel personally uncomfortable to be connected with a -- certain kind of woman, I'm sure you understand. Do you? Well I'd like to buy Jane McKenna's book.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: You have no idea what I'm talking about.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Yes -- Jane McKenna's book -- I could make a phone call.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: No, you're frightened, you're pretending. Well -- Klute knows about me then. Does everybody know, can you tell me?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Then it doesn't matter what I do any more, does it?

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: I'm not going to hurt you, absolutely, I'm not.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Will you let me go then?

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: It puzzles me so badly. I've done terrible things but I can't consider myself a terrible man. I've killed three people and I'd still want to say it was accident, do you see?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: If you'll let me go I could tell them what --

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Tom Grunemann discovered me -- we were here on business together, he discovered me with Jane McKenna. Then I suppose it was the -- the contempt I saw in his face and the certainty that sooner or later he'd use it against me. Within the Company. I endured that as long as I could, do you see?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I'm sorry, I'm just frightened. Yes.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Excuse me Miss Daniel?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I said yes, I see.

turns.speaker: CABLE
turns.text: Oh no, I don't think --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Tell me. I'll listen.  I just want you to tell me.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Miss Daniel? My name is Klute -- John Klute --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What about?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: My name's John Klute.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You said that.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I'm an investigator. I'd like to ask you some questions about Tom Grunemann.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Tom Grunemann. He wrote you some letters.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Gee.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: He was a research engineer at the Tuscarora Laboratories in Pennsylvania. He disappeared from there last April. I've been hired to look for him.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: You know what I'm talking about. Miss Daniel.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Honest?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Will you let me ask you some questions?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Dew yew hayuv ah-dentifikyshun?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You're not police or FBI; you're just a private investigator?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: And you just want to ask me a few questions?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Is it the shakedown hon? You picked a loser, I just don't have it.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No, I'm look --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: If I was taking calls full time would I be living in this kip? I'd be back on Park Avenue; I could support the whole National Guard!

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Could I ask some questions?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Or you'll get me shoved back in the brig you mean; another month with the bull-dykes.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Company outing or picnic or something like that.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Isn't that sweet.  Well it could be any one of them bubi; I get to see them all.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: A name. Grunemann. Nothing. And they showed me pictures like this and they meant nothing. Then they asked me, well had I been getting letters, from someone out there in Cabbageville --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: -- Tuscarora --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: All right, yes, I had been. Those sick, wild letters -- I'm watching you, gonna follow you, gonna punish you, kill you et cetera. Well, they said, all right that's Grunemann. So try to remember when you and he - when -- well I don't know, there was that dumper once, he sounded like that dumper --  Dumpers; they get their kicks beating you up. A man hired me once, then tried to really kill me - that'd be about two years ago.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You remind me of my uncle.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What?  What do you remember about that -- dumper?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Nothing. Except he wasn't kidding. Usually it's a fakeout, you probably know. They pretend to tie you up, and you wear a dress with a cloth belt and they pretend to whip you or you --  Hell it's their money. I'll hang from the shower rod and whistle Maytime. Except this guy was really tripped out on it; he --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: But you can't say that Dumper was Tom Grunemann.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I can't say he was anybody!

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well could I have them back now hon? -- those tape recordings you've got downstairs -- OK? -- and if you want you can have a good time and I'll have a good time and--

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What about everything since?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Everything that's happened since Tom Grunemann disappeared. The phone calls and the --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Just phone calls, right? They ring, you answer, they don't say anything, just blank. Kids getting kicks. Burglars looking for an empty apartment. I mean there is nothing that proves --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What about the other things you've reported? --  -- being followed on the --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Look -- I'm sorry -- I've led everybody wrong. I mean yes, I get those feelings, but that's just me, that's just feelings.  I'm sure this will amuse you; I'm scared of the dark. And sometimes I get shook up, I hear people or -- well, I'll come out in the morning and think someone's been prying at my mailbox, or there's a little -- trash outside my door and I wonder if someone left it there for -- do you see? -- things other people wouldn't even notice. Well that's not real, it's just nerves; it's got nothing to do with --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Is that how you get most of your dates? Someone gives your name to someone else?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Most of them.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Is that how you met the Dumper? -- Someone else gave --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: How would I remember?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: How else do you meet them? Pimps?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You're very square. Pimps don't get you dates, cookie; they just take the money.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I have some names the police gave me. Frank Ligourin. Will you tell me what --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Look, I'm sure this'll amuse you too. Ilia trying to get away from all that.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What about the old gentleman the other night, Mr. Faber?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Klute, tell me, what's your bag? Are you a talker, or a button man or a doubler, or maybe you like them very young -- children -- or get your chest walked around with high-heeled shoes, or have us watch you tinkle? Or --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: -- You want to wear women's clothes, or you get off ripping things --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: -- you perverted hypocrite square bastards.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Gee I hope this doesn't make my cold any worse.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Tell me about Frank Ligourin.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Mm? Oh, he was my old man. We broke up.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What? This?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: -- OK?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I thought you could trick me for those tapes. Don't you get lonely in that little green room? Or let me get you someone; I have terrific friends, wild.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You've changed your mind? You do want to play?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I don't want you to look up. There's someone on the skylight.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Tell me about acting -- what are you doing tomorrow -- where do you go?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I go on rounds.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Rounds, what are they? -- don't watch me, keep talking.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You go see agents -- or Equity calls, open casting calls. And ad agencies -- commercials -- you don't get work, you just go around.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well do you think it was him?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Can't you get him?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Maybe, if you tell me the things you haven't.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You asked me where I got that date with the dumper -- Frank sent me on it.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Do you know where he got the dumper?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: He never told me.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Well, let's go down and ask him.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What did you expect? Frankie still has a good string, three girls. Figure three hundred a week from each.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Is that what you gave him?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Did you like my friend Frankie?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Didn't he tell you what you wanted?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It didn't go anywhere.  But that's not why --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: About the dumper, didn't he tell you that?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It was Jane McKenna who sent you the dumper.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well -- she's dead.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I thought you were going back to the apartment.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: You said you wanted these.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh golly, oh just what I've always dreamed of, dirty phone calls.  How come?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: You told me what you could. I guess I'm through with your part of it.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Is there anything more I could --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I don't see anything, do you?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What're you gonna do next?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Try some other ways.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What do I do meanwhile? -- wait for that clown to fall through the skylight on me?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: And I don't think that was Tom.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You said it was!

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No, I said what did you think.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh -- wait -- oh I get it. You said that just to keep me scared. So I'd tell you everything I -- oh clever; oh you smart, tricky hick.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Well --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Hey, but did we get to you, Klute? A little?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Yeah, you got to me.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: -- Us city folks? The sin, the glitter, the wickedness?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Oh. No. Not that way. I'd say it was more -- I don't know --  -- too bad? Pathetic?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: It's kind of late.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: It got lonely upstairs. There's someone on the roof.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh, don't be a doo-doo.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Not much point to this, is there?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Ezra, I'm lots better than you're used to. Tell me -- the other night, watching me with Mr. Faber -- wasn't your tongue a little bit hanging out?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: So you're not too different from him, or the chap on the roof, or Tommy-baby --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Bree -- thanks -- I don't want to.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh don't be all hypocrite. Or do you really like other kicks? Is it more just having power over someone? -- so you don't really need to --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What's the matter hon? You were great. Terrific. A tiger.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well what're you down about? You mean because you didn't get me there?  You can't expect that. I mean Frank, yes, he'd get me there all the time -- but never with a John.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: You asked if there was anything more you could help me with.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I've checked the records of Jane McKenna's death -- I can't get anything special. But Frank Ligourin had another girl you said, besides McKenna and you.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Arlyn Page.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Did she and Jane McKenna know each other?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Frankie kept them in the same apartment: it cut his travel-time.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Then maybe Arlyn Page knew the Dumper too.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Arlyn had a very big habit - heroin - she's the one who started Frank. She's strung out now; you won't find her.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: You could help me find her. You know the people.  I'll pay you a hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I can make that in a lunch break!  Look, Hiram, you're sure it isn't just me? -- you decided you liked it, after all, the other night; you'll hang around for seconds?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Don't worry.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What the hell do you think's the matter.  I could wait for you someplace.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: If Arlyn Page is living with Tom Grunemann --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: -- Then you don't need me.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: But if it's someone else I do.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I thought you ought to know, Arlyn Page is dead.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: The same as Jane McKenna.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Thanks for the jolly news. I thought maybe you'd left town by now. You kind of just disappeared. But you boys from Tuscarora have a habit of disappearing, don't you?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: The next few weeks I would like to know where you are all the time.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Just let me know when you are going out and where --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: What if i go out on tricks - you wanna come along? You could sit and read the National Geographic.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: How can you do it to yourself?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I don't get you.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Ligourin: How could you do it?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I told you before, you wouldn't understand.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: You're right, I don't understand. Explain it to me.  You were scared. Arlyn Page, that scared you. Well it should; that's death. So what did you do, you ran straight for it, death. Ligourin kills women.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No, no you're right, I'm sorry. He uses women; he lets them kill themselves. Is that how you want it?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Arlyn was a junkie; I'm not on junk!

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: No, you can find some other way.  Explain it to me. Bree, show me any sense to --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You get the Christ out! You dumb stupid bastard, you don't know anything, you square, you get out! I don't have to show you anything; you get out!

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: We did this before.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: No.  Well all right. But you want to and I want you to and we both know it and all right.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I don't like getting splashed.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I'm still scared.  I mean different but still.  Look, I made it very clear from the start, you're a yokel, you don't excite me, you don't even interest me, and so I only have one question which is what the hell are you doing in my bed?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: My bed.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I am scared. The things I do. The things I could do to you.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: No, not just 'mm'. You don't know what I --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh boy, say, you think you're pretty good.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: I saw Mr. Faber.  You remember Mr. Faber, don't you?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Is that all you have to say?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What am I supposed to say?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Well, I told him I wouldn't - uh - go there any more.  I know it's tough to understand, but it wasn't easy. You see, he was nice to me. I mean, it wasn't just him. I got something out of it too I guess. Anyway, I told him I wouldn't go there anymore.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Spangler says we have a relationship.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You and I -- a relationship.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I was wondering what that was.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Hell there's nothing so mysterious about the square life.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh Jesus. Oh Jesus.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Don't touch anything.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh look what he did in them.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Drop it.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Listen to me: It's all right. I've been expecting something.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: My God, I thought it was over. And here I am, daddy, right back at the start.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Bree --

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Right back at the start, right?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Go down in my room.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: You said it was over, right? You said not to worry any more, all over, right?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Ah, Schmendrick -- what's the scam?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Those were police laboratory people, they've been over the apartment.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Oh zippidy-doo, they'll find my fingerprints.  Can I go in? I need some stuff.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Where'd you spend last night?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: With Trina.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: I called Trina.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Maybe I wasn't there when you called.

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Bree, what's actually happened? It wasn't that bad.

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: How do you know how bad it was?

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Why couldn't you stay here with me?

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Because I didn't want to be touched! I didn't think you'd get that!

turns.speaker: BREE
turns.text: Hey -- look officer -- I can explain everything. It was just -- you know, everything all of a --

turns.speaker: KLUTE
turns.text: Trask wants to talk with you.
